questions.question: A study on the prevalence of diabetes was conducted and the sampling method shown belowwas used. Identify the sampling method used.
questions.explanation: In this study, the population is separated into homogenous sub-groups and from these, randomsamples are drawn. This sampling method is called stratified random sampling.

questions.question: In which of the following sampling techniques is design effect used?
questions.explanation: 890The design effect is used in cluster sampling to allow for design structure and correlation betweenclusters.The design effect (DEFF) is used to decide the sample size needed for cluster sampling. This isdone by calculating the difference in sampling variability to the variability expected with simplerandom sampling (SRS).It can more simply be stated as the actual sample size divided by the effective sample size (whatyou would expect if you were using SRS). For example, let's say you were using cluster sampling.A DEFF of 2 means the variance is twice as large as you would expect with SRS. It also means thatif you used cluster sampling, you'd have to use twice the sample size.

questions.question: Simple random sampling is ideal for which of the following study groups?

options.A: A study being conducted on all vaccinated people of an area
options.B: A study on occupational exposure in all workers of the same factory
options.C: A study being conducted on prevalence of acute gastroenteritis in all school children of an area
options.D: A study on prevalence of hypertension in men aged 50-75 years in an area

questions.explanation: Simple random sampling is ideal for a homogeneous population as the sample would becompletely representative of the population and it would eliminate the need for systematization orstratification. Here, workers of the same factory form a homogeneous population.Option A: For a vaccinated population - cluster samplingOptions C and D: For a heterogeneous population - stratified sampling
questions.chapter_heading: Facets of Clinical Research and Biostatistics

questions.question: In a study, first schools were sampled, then sections and finally students. What is this type ofsampling known as?
questions.explanation: Multistage sampling is the taking of samples in stages using smaller and smaller sampling units ateach stage. It involves dividing the population into groups (or clusters). Then, one or moreclusters are chosen at random and everyone within the chosen cluster is sampled.Snowball sampling is a type of non-random sampling preferred in case of diseases with socialstigma (eg., alcoholism, iv drug abuse etc).

questions.question: For an epidemiological study, sampling was done as shown below. What is this type ofsampling known as?
questions.explanation: Systematic sampling involves a systematic pattern to sampling, like choosing every 3rd personfrom an area or hospital, etc.

questions.question: In a study, subjects were assigned according to the potential factor that will influence theoutcome of the study. What is this type of sampling known as?
questions.explanation: In stratified random sampling, the population is first divided into homogeneous groups or strata.From these strata, random samples are drawn.For example: If a researcher wants to conduct a research study to determine if alcoholconsumption is a risk factor for lung cancer. He must first stratify the population into smokersand non-smokers because smoking is a known risk factor and also smoking is associated with891alcohol consumption.

questions.question: A study was done to assess the risk factors for breast cancer in 100 females from urban cities.A statistical group and analysis are shown below. The values indicate the odds ratio and the95% confidence interval. How many risk factors may be ascertained from the statisticalanalysis of the research?

options.D: 6Early menarche1.3 (1.2-1.9)Age < 50 yrs0.04 (0.01-0.32)SmokingBRCA Mutation0.5 (0.02-0.9)1.9 (1.1-2.8)AlcoholHigh socioeconomicstatusObesityNo family historyof Ca. breast

questions.explanation: Among the factors shown in the above statistical group, the odds ratio of early menarche,BRCA mutation, and obesity show positive association and are statistically significant. Hencethese 3 factors can be ascertained as risk factors.High socioeconomic status is not a risk factor. Even though there is a positive association, it is notstatistically significant. Any association that has a 95% confidence interval range that includes thevalue of 1.0 is considered to be non-significant. The value of 1.0 in the range means that the twofactors may co-exist together but one is not causing the other to happen.Odds ratio (OR) is the key parameter in case-control studies to assess the strength of associationbetween the exposure and outcome. The interpretation of the odds ratio can be done as below:•OR > 1 indicates a positive association. If both upper and lower limits of the 95% confidencelimits are also >1, it suggests that the odds ratio is significant and the factor can be ascertainedas a risk factor.• OR = 1indicates no association. Irrespective of the odds ratio, if the lower limit of 95% CI is <1and the upper limit of 95% CI >1, the OR is non-significant and cannot be ascertained either asa protective or a risk factor.•• OR < 1 indicates a negative association. If both upper and lower limits of the 95% confidencelimits are also <1, it suggests that the odds ratio is significant and the factor can be ascertainedas a protective factor.Interpretation of the individual factors given in the question:FactorOdds ratio (95% confidence limits)InterpretationEarly menarche1.3(1.2-1.9)Age <50 years0.04 (0.01-0.32)Smoking0.5 (0.02-0.9)BRCA mutation1.9 (1.1-2.8)Alcohol1.0 (0.8-1.8)ntHigh socioeconomic status1.4 (0.5-3.5)Obesity1.24 (1.1-1.7)No family history of Ca. brea0.3 (0.01-0.9)stPositive association, significant, risk factorNegative association, significant, protective factorNegative association, significant, protective factorPositive association, significant,risk factorNo association, non-significaPositive association, non-significantPositive association, significant, risk factorNegative association, significant, protective factor893
